STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 15, 2025
Romell G Green
Wayne County DHHS-Western
27540 Michigan Ave.
Inkster, MI, 48141-2202
RE: License#:
CP820201497
Dear Mr. Green:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 10/3/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201497
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Romell G Green
Name of Agency: WAYNE COUNTY DHHS - WESTERN
Agency Address: 27540 MICHIGAN AVE
INKSTER, MI 48141-2202
Agency Telephone #: 3132958017
Original Issuance Date: 05/01/1992
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Place
children in foster home, Supervise
Independent Living

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of competent staff
to carry out the provisions covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member may not be more than any of the following:
(a) Five social service workers per supervisor.
One of six supervisors was out of compliance, in that they had six foster care
workers assigned to them.
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of competent staff
to carry out the provisions covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member may not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for purposes of providing
direct services in foster care, independent living, adoption, or post adoption
services or a combination thereof.
Eight of 22 foster care workers had caseloads over 15, with two workers having
caseloads of 18.

CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance within a probationary
period or not later than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or her
current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written evaluation must be
conducted every 12 months.
Five of 14 new employee records reviewed showed the employee's probationary
performance evaluation was not timely per their respective due dates.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 11/27/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the child's record before a
change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties, including the child or infant,
which includes an explanation as to why the change is necessary.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed, where the child was replaced on
3/18/2025; 3/24/2025 and 3/26/2025 respectively, did not show documentation of
the replacement preparation for all relevant parties, as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the child's record before a
change of placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer guardian ad litem, and courts
when applicable, of the change in placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed, where the child was replaced on
3/18/2025; 3/24/2025 and 3/26/2025 respectively, did not show documentation
that each of these parties:parents, lawyer guardian ad litem and or court, were
notified of the change.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.

(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a foster home, then
both the following must be documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the time of the change
in placement and the needs that remain to be met.
Two of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not document summary of
services provided during care or did not document the needs that remain to be
met, as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the child's record before a
change of placement occurs:
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R 400.12404(4).
One of eight open foster child records reviewed where the child was replaced on
3/18/2025; 3/24/2025 and 3/26/2025 respectively, did not show documentation of
the consideration factors identified in R400.1204(4), as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the child's record before a
change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new placement, consistent
with the requirements of R 400.12417.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed where the child was replaced on
3/18/2025; 3/24/2025 and 3/26/2025 respectively, did not show documentation
that information about the child consistent with R400.12417 was shared with the
caregiver at the time of placement, as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a foster home, then
both the following must be documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Two of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not document whether there
was any provision for continuing services, as required by the rule.

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by section 5111 of the public
health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the waiver is unavailable, then
immunizations must begin within 30 calendar days of placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's
DTP/DTaP/DT/Td/Tdap immunization expired 4/14/2025; and an updated
immunization was not documented.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3 months before entry into
foster care or an initial dental examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home placement. A child
entering foster care under 1 year of age must have an initial dental exam within 3
months of his or her first birthday.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
the child's initial dental exam which was due by 2/15/2025; three months after the
child's turned one year old.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 11/27/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation from the medical or dental
provider of all medical and dental care received by a foster child.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed, the record did not show
documentation of the child's 5/22/2025 dental exam as received from the dental
provider.

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the foster parents in
the development of service plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and the foster
parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give
a copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is confidential.
In four of eight open foster child records reviewed the respectively record did not
show that all treatment plans were reviewed and signed timely by all parties.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023, cited under FOM 722-8D.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a), must include all the
following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as required under R
400.12404(4).
In two of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's initial service plan
did not document the placement selection criteria.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 11/27/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a), must include all the
following information:
(h) The child behavior support plan to be used by the foster parent.
In three of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's initial service plan
did not show documentation of a specific behavior support plan for the child to be
used by the foster parent.

CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b), must include all
the following information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any changes made since the
previous plan and is to be used by the foster parents.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed two of the reviewed updates
services plan did not show documentation of a specific behavior support plan for
the child to be used by the foster parents.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between siblings who are not
placed together except when there is a court determination that contact is
detrimental to either child.
In one of eight open child records reviewed, where siblings were split, the record
did not show documentation of a December 2024 sibling visit.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a youth before
placement in independent living.
One of one independent living records reviewed did not show documentation that
a copy of the agency's program statement was provided to the youth before
placement.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following information and documentation,
which must be recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:

(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient to meet the youth's
housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses.
One of one independent living records reviewed did not show documentation of
current financial support sufficient to meet the youth’s needs.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R400.12405-3(e): Change of placement: The agency was apprised it shall
clearly and consistently describe how all parties were prepared; and that stating
"all parties were notified of the changes" does not describe how they were
prepared.
• R400.12417(g)(h): Foster parent information: The agency was apprised it shall
clearly and consistently document all areas related to information provided to
foster parents at placement.
• R400.12422(2)(g): Foster care case record: The agency was apprised it shall
consistently and timely upload each of the child's annual photos.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R400.12417 Foster parent information: The agency was advised ensuring its
workers consistently fill in all areas on the Placement Outline-(DHS-3307) form it
utilizes to document the information required by this rule, may aid it in showing
ongoing compliance to this rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. The CAP related to the agency’s 2024 Interim inspection where it
received 6 rules violations, where 2 of those were repeat violations. During this
year’s Renewal inspection, the agency received 19 rule violations. Of these 19
violations, 6 of them are repeat violations, and 3 of the 6 are repeat citations from
the 2024 Interim inspection. Of the 3 repeat violations from the 2024 Interim
inspection, the number of individual cases cited remained the same for 2 of them.
It was 1 of 8 in each instance; which were related to R400.413(1)(e) for Medical
and dental policy; and R400.12419(1)(c) for Initial service plans. In terms of the
third repeat violations, the number of individual cases cited remained basically the
same. The number of individual cases, for this citation, which was for
R400.1212(3)(a) for Personnel records, was 7 of 18 in 2024; and 5 of 14 this
inspection.
Notwithstanding the increase in the number of rule violations this inspection, the
agency implemented all action steps within its 2024 Interim inspection CAP. Its
efforts moving forward are to bring greater compliance in all areas and more timely
uploaded documentation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 9/29/2025. The chief
administrator (CA) reported on the prior year's violations, and the action steps it
put in place to achieve compliance. The CA indicated the CAP had measurable
impacts in that now orientation and training is documented systematically; and
evaluation timeliness have improved with proactive reminders, as have medical
and dental compliance through HLO’s (Health Liaison Officer) involvement and
weekly reminders. The CA also reported key barriers like CPS staff turnover, high
caseloads and staff being on extended leave were factors that contributed to
delays in rule compliances
The CA reported compliance monitoring will continue to occur via monthly
supervisory case conferences; quarterly audits by section managers and the
quality staff, as well as district-wide KPI meetings, and quarterly all staff meetings,
which the agency believes will have positive aspects. The CA further reported an
increase in cases coming in, despite the difficulties that may come with that, has
allowed case workers to become more adaptable to changes, and to facilitate
complex case management. Additional strengths noted by the CA are the
agency’s site being deemed a 24-hour facility, allowing them the ability to be more
accommodating to families and allowing more opportunity to supervise
parent/child visitations; staff’s ability to engage families; and allocation of an
additional social service assistance which can provide case support to workers.
The agency also reported it shall continue all efforts to improve and achieve
ongoing rule compliance.

Financial Overview
Not applicable
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the current chief administrator, section managers,
administrative assistant and supervisors, three foster workers and two supervisors
were interviewed. The staff interviewed reported numerous strengths and
positives attributes for the agency. Those strengths included management not
micro-managing staff, a structured office environment, approachable coworkers,
an amicable and approachable district manager, the sunshine morale committee;
monthly program meetings; the help of quality assurance staff, a good chain of
command and now having their own district director. As for areas of
improvements needed, this included implementation of a trainer/the training unit
for new foster care staff, a reduction in case load sizes; supervisors being more
proactive with educating workers on what tasks are required of them as opposed
to asking them why they did not complete a task, when the worker may not have
known to complete that task; more staff ; and CWTI training being modified to
address practical components of the job.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through in the agency's office showed the agency has sufficient space and
equipment for its staff. The agency has gone paperless, and so current and
closed records are electronic files and are secure.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two safety alerts identified.
Safety Alert # 1: There were no operable smoke detectors on each level of
occupancy and or near all sleeping spaces. There is no carbon monoxide detector
in the home.
Resolution: An agency worker made a home visit on 9/3/2025 at which time the
worker provided the caregiver with three combination smoke/carbon monoxide
detectors. The worker assisted the caregiver in installing the three detectors and
ensured they were working. Photos were provided showing that the detectors were
installed.
Alert #2: There was no operable smoke detector on the second level of the home.
Resolution: On 9/10/2025 the agency worker visited the caregiver's home and
provided the caregiver with a new smoke detector. The worker ensured the device
was properly installed and was in working order. Photos were attached showing the
detector's installation.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
October 13, 2025
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 15, 2025

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
